AN (UN) HELPFUL GUIDE TO BECOME A MDZS FAN:-

* keep reading the novel to the last , start with either manhua ( you can read it on my reading manga or mangago) or donghua( HERE) because there are so many characters and its really difficult to keep up with!

* The live adaptation is really beautiful , and if you dont wanna read the book watch it because its really one of the most beautiful dramas in the world! ( HERE/ NETFLIX/ WE TV APP)


* FINALLLLYYYYYY THE BOOK OMG, ITS NOT OFFICIALLY TRANSLATED BUT I READ IT FROM( HERE) , AND ITS THE BEST TRANSLATION WE HAVE RIGHT NOW!

Katrina
144 reviews
May 20, 2020
This is one of the best translated c-novels out there. Exiled Rebels' translation quality is excellent. And the book itself, is a holy wow.

Before anything, this novel is categorized as BL, or boy love. So yes there is a gay romance. But don't let that stop you from reading this masterpiece. This novel is 10% super slowly hinted romance (the best kind), 10% complex relationships with side characters, and 80% killing demons and solving mysteries. It's basically an epic adventure. The character development and pacing is extremely well done. I just finished reading 74 translated chapters, and I am now in book hangover territory. The novel is still being translated, one chapter a week.

The main character is Wei Wuxian. He is a troublemaker with good intentions. He is shameless, mischievous, reckless and an arrogant super genius. He single-handedly started demonic cultivation. During the sunshot campaign, he used his dark powers to fight against tyranny and oppression, thus earning him a legendary reputation. After the war, people feared and misunderstood him. Eventually, the dark path took a toll on his temperament. Wei Wuxian got out of control, was betrayed and was killed.

13 years later, Wei Wuxian is summoned into the body of a gay lunatic. The deal is that he gets to possess the lunatic's body for life, but he has to fulfill the original owner of the body's revenge wish. Along with that, he is also hiding his real identity because a lot of people hate/fear him for the demonic things he did in the past. Somewhere along the way, common goals align and he goes on a journey/adventure with Lan Wangji, an old friend from the past, who helps him hide his identity and stays by his side. Lan Wangji is very prim and proper, he is a stickler for rules, and the silent type. He has mastered the art of poker face and doesn’t show his emotions. Both men are badasses and there are a lot of hilarious interactions between the two of them.

I also liked reading about the flashbacks of the past, showing us how the characters met, Wei Wuxian's relationships with side characters (like the backstory with his sworn brother Jiang Cheng) and how Wei Wuxian turned to the dark arts and became the infamous grandmaster.

This book will take a while to get into. The first few chapters are really heavy with world building and character introduction. What's more, each character has three names - a birth name, a more formal name and a title. There are also a lot of different sects, with each character belonging to a certain sect. So that took a while to get used to. But once I got past all those important details, the story got better and better. Trust me.

If you like action and adventure, slow-burn romance, paranormal mysteries, humor, well-developed characters, ancient fantasy world settings, then this is for you.

The donghua (chinese anime) is also one of the best I’ve ever watched. I recommend everyone to watch the donghua after reading a few chapters of the novel. The donghua is on WeTV: https://wetv.vip/en/play/r8t02fkxr9jy...

UPDATE: Because a lot of people keep asking in the comments, the English translation is here: https://exiledrebelsscanlations.com/n...

Also, there is a now Netflix TV series based on this novel called The Untamed, and it rocked big time.
    chinese-novels fantasy favorites

Saswati
508 reviews346 followers
July 25, 2021
5+ STARS ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐



Song recommendation: Jab Se Mera Dil Tera Hua ♪♪

Oh my freaking God!! Is this what a three month reading slump results in? If so, then I got no complaints. None at all. Even though more than half of 2021 is still left, I declare this book right here MY TOP READ OF THIS YEAR 😌

Warning: This ain't a review, it's just me fangirling all over the place 💯

After devouring both The Untamed (highly recommend!) and the adorable donghua Q adaptation of this story, I was still craving more of Wei Wuxian and Lan Wangji. So I looked up this book and decided to give it a try. But I was a bit hesitant cuz I'd never read a Cnovel before, and the word count alone is enough to make me wanna die (500k+). Moreover it was in third person POV sooooo... Y'all get the point. However, this book right here? It's an absolute masterpiece.

Mo Dao Zu Shi (the actual Chinese name if this book) is set in an ancient fantasy world. It has a brilliantly complex, and dark storyline that is full of twists and turns – aaaannd amazing villains. The angst, the plot, the fluff and the freaking superbness of it all blew my mind. I loved it so damn much! And when I say ✨Wangxian gave me life✨, I mean those words with all my heart cuz they really, REALLY did ♥♥♥

Read the beautiful English translation of the novel here

P.S.: If someone loved me even a tenth of how much Lan Zhan loved his Wei Ying, my life would be complete 😭

P.P.S.: Some Wangxian content to bless our eyes 👀

Ellie
579 reviews2,416 followers
Read
August 22, 2020
AFTER 520k WORDS, 113 CHAPTERS, 3 MONTHS AND THE LONGEST ANGSTY SLOWBURN EVER, I HAVE FINISHED MO DAO ZU SHIIIIIIIIII *cries*

what do I do now

It's been an experience, really. Watching the dongua adaption, watching live action adaption (would recommend watching an adaption before starting the book actually, as it helps one get a better sense of the characters/the character's multiple names and titles - the live action version 'the untamed' is on netflix), reading the manhua and then finally finishing the novel. The level of creativity the fans have in this fandom is also no joke - the art is incredible and the fanfic is top-tier. I have an entire dedicated internet folder, if you ever want recs just hmu >:)

I think I want to write an entire post/review with my thoughts later on (especially because I loved the themes/tropes, including 'doing what you think is right even if everyone is against you'/the antihero arc/the slowburn/the juniors with one shared braincell, but had some other quibbles - like the narrative voice and lack of female characters, which is fixed a bit in the live action adaption) but for now I'll leave it here.

but hey @ whoever recommended MDZS to me, you really introduced me to something awesome. I plan to float through the blissful land of the MDZS fandom for eternity. I only exist here now. Job? Friends? What are they. I only know wangxian.

Xia and the Giant TBR
Author 5 books196 followers
May 25, 2020
Okay, let's face it.
I cannot possibility give MDZS 5 stars from a literary perspective and it breaks my heart I need to remove 1 star for the following:
1. Omniscient narrator with too much telling. I am being told the thoughts, emotions and characters' reasons for acting in one way or another
2. Too many flashbacks sneaking up on the reader at the wrong time e.g as the MCs are about to have sex.
3. An ending that was too subtle for my tastes (but the ending was compensated by the 14 extras available, so hey ho)

However!

This 520,000 words book has dominated my life for the past month.

It's one of the best xianxia (Chinese martial arts fantasy) I HAVE EVER READ.

Lan WangJi and Wei WuXian will forever hold a spot in my heart.

There is no official Chinese- English translation. The heroes are the voluntary fan translators that have spent 2 years of their lives to translate this book without requesting anything in return.

Worldbuilding - a thousand stars

Character development - The development of the MCs is just WOW! Also there is a huge array of supporting characters, each with impressive backgrounds and developmental arcs. I have fallen in love with all of them, even the villains.

Music, music, music!

Chinese Daoist Philosophy.

The hype over this book is real.

I don't know if this is a book for the MM Romance community. But if you love danmei or yaoi and are already familiar with the Chinese xianxia genre, I highly recommend it. 

In my heart of hearts this book is 5 stars.

A low bow for our beautiful boys:
    a-long-time-ago-in-asia action danmei

January 18, 2023
Just like before, Wei WuXian called his name with a grin, and he looked over as well.
From then on, he could never move his eyes again.

YALL SAY HELLO TO MY LONGEST REVIEW TILL DATE AND NEWEST OBSESSION- WANGXIAN

I've watched the donghua, I've read the novel, I'm watching the live adaptation AND ITS STILL NOT ENOUGH THE LOVE I HAVE FOR MDZS AND LITERALLY EVERYONE IN IT DHJSJAJSKSK MDZS OWNS MY ASS

Before I start simping over WangXian, I just wanna say- Nie Huaisang, you're perfect and adorable and I love you and your fan and your manipulative brain and can you set me up with your older brother please? 🛐

Also, I've said this before and I'll say this again- Lan Xichen deserves the world and lots of hugs. I just love how he's the sweetest character unless you're so dense you don't realise his brother is in love with you and still flirt with the poor guy relentlessly WE STAN A PROTECTIVE BROTHER ✋🏻 He's also the biggest WangXian shipper so there's that too.

"You were the only mistake he made!"

shut up lxc hes in love

"But he said... that he could not say with certainty whether what you did was right or wrong, but no matter what, he was willing to be responsible for all of the consequences alongside you."

imnotcryingimnotcryingimnotcryingimnotcrying

I have conflicting feelings for (leaning more towards LOATHING) Jin Guangyao bcs I can't really see past what he did with all of my children but at the same time, if my backstory was as bad as his, I'd go all murderer on everyone's asses too. Plus he was also the one who got through WWX's thick skull so bonus points, you see. Also, what he said in the last to LXC, LIKE THATS A LOVE CONFESSION IF IVE EVER HEARD ONE. Idek why people ship him with Nie Mingjue, he's obviously mine there's a better ship right in front of y'all. No, but I actually don't even think he deserves LXC in the first place but moving on-

Wen Ning, my son, the joy of my life- why did MXTX have to do the sweetest (yes, even more than LXC) kid in the book like that but I love how OP he got after that so itsok. I'll protect him and LWJ's (and mine) ducklings with my life.

I'm a slut for Wen Qing. That's it.

Jin Zixuan and Jiang Yanli deserved better. fuck you JGY

Xue Yang, WHY SO FUCKING HOT LET ME LOVE MY ALREADY 36727281818 LOVES IN PEACE OK I DONT WANNA ADD ANOTHER MORALLY BLACK CHARACTER TO THE LIST.

I love love A-Qing, she's THE bitch.

Am I the only one who got Xie Lian vibes from Xiao Xingchen??? (he even looks like XL in the donghua) Also, Song Lan sounds so similar to San Lang and yes these two made me miss HuaLian like no other.

The ducklings need a special mention too bcs I've adopted them and I'm a proud mother. I wanna hug Jin Ling so bad pls he's so cute in the donghua I feel like pinching his cheeks whenever he pouts. 😭 Also, his character development is like nobody's business. Lan Sizhui or A-Yuan is literally WangXian's love child and the way Lan Zhan was with him on their lunch date is going to be ingrained in my brain forever. Lan Jingyi, he's the most like WWX AND IM ALL FOR IT. My kids. 🥺🧿

I saved my husband for the last. Now see, I agree Jiang Cheng is an absolute asshole to literally everyone in the whole book but he's fr the most real and most relatable man there is. ALSO HE'S HOT- I was a goner the first time I saw him in the donghua. I don't condone all that he did and honestly, I hated him too most of the times, especially the way he was with both WWX AND JL but he's trying okay. 😭 He also gives me major Bakugou Katsuki vibes and that boy is everything to me so there's that. He just needs a good therapist and good sex and good booze and good communication skills AND IM FOREVER GONNA BE A JIANG CHENG APOLOGIST.

"WangJi, what happened?"
"Wei Ying."

Show me a better ship than WangXian. YOU CANT. (I'm not counting HuaLian and Kanej and ToryDarius that would be blasphemy)

He wasn't scared of falling. All these years, he'd fallen many times. But falling on the ground still hurt, after all. If someone was there to catch him, it'd be more than wonderful.

If HuaLian invented love, WangXian is the reason love exists.

Wei Ying, my man, he exudes chaotic bi and I'm all for it. For a self-proclaimed flirt, he was so dense for most of the book it wasn't even funny. 😭

This dude actually could not stop talking about how handsome and pretty Lan Wangji is to anybody who would listen to him and then he has the audacity to say he's straight. YOURE NOT STRAIGHT MY LOVE YOURE JUST A DUMBASS.

"You're really great. I like you. Or in other words, I fancy you, I love you, I want you, I can't leave you, I whatever you. I want to night-hunt with you for the rest of my life."

But when AND how he confessed?? No shit I was jumping between giggling and screaming bcs these two retards were finally together and they were finally happy and LWJ finally got the love of his life in his arms and I finally got the inherent happiness I get whenever my ship sails.

His backstory hurt like no other. I cried so many times for how it ended for him. This man, he lost so much and the way he died, I'm never getting over it. And yes, he was never the same after all that happened. But, people who say he turned evil can go fuck off bcs he didn't. And even if he did, I would support him fully bcs the bastards who wronged this perfection deserve Evil Wei Ying.

Lan WangJi was now the only one who stood by his side. Luckily, Lan WangJi was also the only one he wished to have by his side.

Lan Zhan is one of the best LIs I've ever read about. The way he fights, in the most literal sense, every fucking one for Wei Ying ajskkakskk my heart couldn't handle it really.

But what he hadn't expected was that when everyone feared him and flattered him, Lan WangJi scolded him right in his face; when everyone spurned him and loathed him, Lan WangJi stood by his side.

SOBBING

"You saw it with your own eyes?"
"He saw with his own eyes."
"You believe in him?"
"I do."

The way he trusts WWX and is always there for him. 😭 They're both so stupid ughhh if only they'd just talked like normal people instead of whatever homoerotic rivalry/tension they had going on (even though that was a treat in itself), I would've been spared from so much pain. But they got their happy ending in the end and that's all that matters.

"Wrong. Not 'us', but 'me'. I think the only person he's watching is you."

It's the way everyone knows LWJ is in love with WWX except WWX. Also, drunk LWJ? Cute. Jealous LWJ? Cuter. Drunk AND jealous LWJ? CUTEST.

It's not even the romance. The plot, the world-building, all the characters, the plot twists- its all so fucking good and mind-boggling. I honestly can't recommend MDZS enough. Seriously ppl, do yourself and me a favour and read this masterpiece. 🛐

PS- I still have the extra chapters to read and I'm kinda scared bcs I've actually been told they're traumatizing but it's more WangXian so I'm gonna do it! 😤

PPS- I live for WangXian fluff and the extras served. Also, we got the children and I'm in heaven. 😩 The last two chapters were everything oml. 😭 Most of these reminded me of the chibi version (especially the lotus seeds one) Wangji was such a big simp and WWX was really stupid asf- he couldn't stop talking about LWJ. 😭 They have my whole fucking heart. 😩🫶🏻

November 29, 2020
I realized how empty my life before i knew Wei Wu Xian and Lan Wang Ji and their love story!

I read this because i love the Netflix Chinese Drama “The Untamed” the show hit the most popular show in China on 2019.. originally this show is adapted from this book, because of the China censorship they cannot show the LGBT romance through the show and turned it into Bromance story instead so the show left me with this yearning feeling to see my ship officially sailing.

This is also the first time i read Chinese book written by Chinese author ( there is no official English translation but i read the Eng version through this website: https://exiledrebelsscanlations.com/n...)

Read this book was such an amazing experience, i love the mystery element and adventure (which is ussually a miss for me, i dislike Travelling story) but in this book... i truely enjoyed my journey, never a boring moment!! the character developments are amazing i love every single one of them even the villain! and the ROMANCE OOOOOHHHHH MY GOODNESSSSSS, i can declare this is one of the most heartbreaking and beautiful love story i have ever read!!! Romeo & Juliet can step a side and give a way to WangXian! i laughed, cried in repeat to the point i almost think i go insane, i love this couple so much!!! 🤣😂

I can see myself forever in the dark pit of this fandom, there is something so addictive about these characters!!

everyone need to meet Lan Zhan and Wei Ying! now i'm off to watch the animation & read the comic and listen to the audio drama
Anastasia
6 reviews
March 2, 2020
A perfect example of gross fetishizing of gay couples by a straight woman. Author openly admitted to write the main character as a self-insert so she could fantasize about being "plowed" by another main character, and it shows. This is why we get completely unbacked love story where one falls for the other w/o any reason and the other magically turns not only gay but also "perpetual bottom" at a certain point. In addition we get a decent dose of hyperfeminization and imposing of gross heterosexual norms on the couple. We also get dub-con and downright rape scenes that are pitched as "romantic" because the said author has a certain fetish (direct quote from her interview).
The world setting is standard for Xianxia and nothing out of the ordinary (cultivation, sects, ghosts, evil clans), the plot is ok, and it would've been a good book if not for the sheer grossness of what she did to the "love story."
If you want to see the better version of this, watch the Untamed tv show- somehow the screen writers, directors and actors, despite censorship, managed not only to produce a compelling and interesting story, but also added much needed depth and background to most of the major characters. And the Tv show does a PERFECT job of showing the two main characters becoming allies, then friends, and then soulmates. It is not out of the blue, it is a natural development of their relationship, and while there is not even a kiss on screen, only a blind person will doubt that those two are in deep, encompassing love with each other.

5 stars.

August 27, 2022
OK, I totally cheated. I finished reading Vol 3 of the Grandmaster of Demonic Cultivation and I had to know what happened. I went to a translation site and read the rest of the story in 2 days. I mean I couldn't put this book down. It was a very decent English translation as well. There are a ton of extra chapters at the end I'm so grateful for.

So, the stuff left out of the show is a shame. I mean, the stuff in the book is amazing and it's way better than the show.

I love this story. Everything is so well done. The books keep saying this was for audience 17 and up and I was like, this is something teens could read until I got further into the story. Yeah, the 17 year old rating is warranted. Once the two get through their issues and the sex starts, it is not shy about it. MXTX delivers on all that stuff. Things you would expect Wei Wuxian to be shameless about, he totally is.

I will buy each English volume as they come out, but it was worth getting to read it all at once. I can't wait to read it again and I will for each volume.

It's too bad the show couldn't deliver more of the relationship to us than it did, it still comes across though, but I like this version better. I'm an MXTX fan for life. I hope she has a new book soon!!!

Yeyu
Author 5 books33 followers
August 11, 2024
Interesting to see this also so hyped on goodreads. I actually rated it 3 stars on saowen since that was the threshold for just ok on that platform, but 2 stars here as it represents just ok on goodreads.

My review is strictly based on the Chinese version and not the translation nor any other adaptions.

Pros:

- Good pacing that keeps you reading and entertained, despite the predictable plot. There were definitely flaws, but it was entertaining enough for me to disregard them. Perhaps I was not invested enough to care about any loose ends since I forgot most of what I read.

- Passable prose

- Humorous to an extent. Improvement from the author's earlier work.

- Much of the cons come as an aftertaste of fridge logic


Not my cuppa/Personal Squicks:

- Appeals to mainstream tastes, specifically the dynamics of a taciturn, mysterious stoic LI top and a noisy, saintly OP (self-insert) MC bottom

- Overall MC is not "Moe" for me, which reduces my enjoyment. As a reader I am primarily motivated by how "Moe" I find the bottom.

- I found scenes with LI/top getting drunk awkward af

- Often miscategorized (imho) as Xiuzhen/Xiuxian genre, when there is no one training for immortality except for perhaps the MC's master. Usually Xiuzhen has a focus on man vs fate/nature (gaining immortality goes against nature), often ultimately becoming man vs gods/Heaven/demons, whereas no such conflict is present in this story. No one in this fic seems to really care about immortality, and the scope of the setting is limited without involving other planes of existence (which is a defining feature of the Xiuzhen genre). At best I think this should be categorized as Xianxia genre. There is magic which does use generic Xiuzhen cultivation system, but the plot revolves around very mortal affairs and soap opera conflict.

- Maybe I'm just too old for this


Cons:

- Juvenile characters and dialogue (not sure how the English translations are, but this is my impression from the Chinese original work). Specifically, teenagers (younger gen) feel like kindergarten children, while adults act/talk/think like teenage girls from junior high. With a serious case of Chuunibyou. Lots of screaming, OTT hysterics. Many side characters seem to have below-average IQ/EQ. I would not have been as annoyed if the fic was super light-hearted and not meant to be taken seriously, but despite the humor, it seems the fic is somewhat meant to be taken seriously.

- MC is right no matter what. People who don't agree with the MC just don't understand how ~selfless~ and ~good~ the saintly MC is, even though MC pretty much acts without considering any negative consequences others must endure thanks to his impulsive heroics. To me it is kinda problematic if the MC's (less severe) problems are shown as always more important/severe than other people's problems. MC is portrayed as a victim and others are shown wronging him for wanting him to take responsibility for something he is mostly responsible for (there was this one dude who always went into hysterics which does not help his case, as it decreases reader sympathy toward the dude and makes readers more sympathetic to MC). Woe is the MC...people just do not understand how holy and selfless his self-righteous intentions were, but as Jesus he will keep his reasons to himself and still save these poor fools, even if they are thankless.... Um... yeah, I'm very uncomfortable with a shallow worldview where everything revolves around the MC, so this is not a story worth re-reading for me. I mostly ignored these issues when I read for the first time because I was more interested in the story.

- Some antagonists are so idiotic it's difficult to feel conflict tension due to how pathetic and weak they are. Same goes to the pedestrian opposition--I remember feeling quite frustrated at how stupid and immature they are, instead of feeling sympathy for the MC as the author might have intended.

Don't get me wrong, I was entertained and did enjoy the story, reading everything in practically one sitting even while I was squicked by several issues. I can see why the story is popular, but I can't say it's a shining example of what the Chinese BL community has to offer.

==edit 2024/8/11==
Recently there's been a huge crackdown in China, which led to the arrest of 200+ BL authors who earn money from work containing explicit sex, and some people mentioned MXTX also getting jailed for earning money from writing BL (she's by far the author who has earned the most money I think).

I'm not sure whether the rumors are true, but that really blows. I'm not a big fan of MXTX's work due to my personal tastes, but I appreciate how it really exposed a lot of people to Chinese Danmei.

I hope the rumors are false and the author is ok (though I did notice she hadn't released any new work for a long time now, wasn't sure if it was because her 3rd book was extremely poorly reviewed for its blatant plagiarism of the "Pili" puppet show TV series.)
    bl chinese fiction
Ari

May 2, 2020
5 completely addicted as fuck to this book for perhaps my entire fucking life at this point stars

Here’s a very short summary of why I adore this book so much:

1. Wei Ying and Lan Zhan: I just adore how on the surface you can’t get two people anymore different from each other, but then the moment you peel off the first cover you realize that they are the exact same person. They share the same morality, view and respect for people, one single brain cell, sense of sacrifice, and crazy ass love for the other. *cries at the sheer perfection*
2. An incredibly huge assortment of very well built characters: Ahh.. I think this just says it all. The character tray is crazy, and the way the author has taken care to give almost everyone at least some compelling backstory is to put it into one word- brilliant.
3. ANGST. Angst. and. A-N-G-S-T: Look guys, you have one person who died a horrible death due to political manipulation and misunderstandings, and the other who waited 13 years in a world that treated the love of his life like trash without knowing if he would ever see him again, and that is just the beginning.
4. Excellent depictions of political ideologies. Urgh, this post is long enough already, so I won’t say much more.
5. How every single character acts as a foil to another: Again another thing that you need to read the book to understand.
6. Look man, we have a guy who turned into a villain solely because Lan Zhan is too fucking pretty. Period. And I just love how every other villain has a really strong moral/circumstantial reason for their acts of villainy, and then there’s this guy.
7. The confession scene: *chefs kiss* ‘nough said.
8. WangXian and rabbits. You will get this if you read the book.

You can read my entire fangirling on my blog here .

Sherwood Smith
Author 161 books37.5k followers
Read
September 5, 2019
Curious about the novel behind the series The Untamed, which series turns out is faithful to the novel, good and not so good.

The translation into English is full of errors in spelling, grammar, and proper use of actual English words, but it was done by an unpaid volunteer out of generosity, so readers who get poked out of the reading experience by that sort of thing should know that going in, be prepared, and be grateful at least there's a translation.

The plot is bent around BL, so don't look for rational logic behind character motivations; there are very few. Most of the plot decisions are manipulated toward maximum angst and hurt/comfort for the leads, whose emotional state often reads adolescent female-gaze. But given that framework, there are some interesting characters, some genuinely comic scenes, and plenty of action between long confessional and comfort scenes.

For English readers peering through the tiny keyhole at the vast world of female-written Chinese novels (some of which get millions of hits in their first week of publication) this appears to be a solid, entertaining example of BL--which is deeply subversive considering the government's attempt to control any hint of homoerotic material in the media world.

Go, girls, go!
    wuxi-xianxia
Tsundoku By the Day &#x1f4da;
245 reviews81 followers
April 25, 2021
4.5 stars

Okay, let me start this review by stating facts: 1) before reading this work I had watched The Untamed then 2) read the ongoing manhua. So, overall, by the time I came to the original source material, I was already fairly acquainted with the plot, characters, and some of the dramatic differences between The Untamed and all the other adaptations. (Note: I haven't watched the anime but I surely will!)

Anyhow, reading Mo Dao Zu Shi was 85% badass action/violence/adventure/plot twists, 10% flirtatious bromancing, 5% romance (including the gay erotic kinky stuff if we include the extra chapters that didn't make it into the canon books. ;) ) Overall, the work was solid. I read it in 3-4 days straight. Be prepared, because you WILL want to read it straight through in one sitting but it's very, very long (127 chapters.)

I will say, however, that I will NEVER rewatch The Untamed the same way again. Now that I know all the gay subtext and content that was watered down, edited, or skipped over--and believe me, the story is sooooooo much more reveiling if the novel is read before you watch the show; I was such a baffoon not to do so--my memory, queer heart and soul have been forever imprinted with the gayness of this book rather than whatever innocent conscience I had previously watched the live-action show with (aka I thought Wei Ying and Lan Zhan were just two best friends...O.O. My innocence is now wrecked.) It should be a crime WeTV had me thinking such things!!!

Overall, the plot was awesome! I kinda wished there was more showing instead of telling but I don't judge too harshly b/c this is a translated work available to read online like a really good Wattpad story. I don't know how to read Simplified Chinese so I don't know if the descriptions are detailed or not but, overall, the character development was amazing. No character was left behind. As I said before, Jiang Cheng in The Untamed was a docial performative piece of sh!t compared to the Jiang Cheng of Mo Dao Zu Shi, who was a homophobic, jealous, and gaslighting asshat who tended to be performative too--the changes might not have been significant to some people but they were enough for me to point them out. The only thing I wish we had gotten a bit more resolution on was Mo Xuanyu. I was always curious about Mo, in the back of my mind, so when nothing came about for him I felt like he was just one big plot device and deserved better especially when Wei Ying pointed out how Mo Xuanyu was known for being shy but was brave enough to sacrifice his body, mind, and soul to resurrect Wei Ying.

Mo Dao Zu Shi did a great job in giving a 360 view of what was going on in Wei Ying's world as where The Untamed did a great job giving us a 360 view of what was going on with the lives of ALL the characters. That being said, I would have loved for the book to have incorporated more of that "360 of all the characters" into the work. I think they were well rounded for the most part but some were definately better developed (in the novel) than others.

Wei Ying and Lan Zhan are just amazing in the book! Wei Ying is my favorite character (as he probably is for most readers.) He’s the “bad boy” everyone just wants to hug. The actor that portrayed him in The Untamed did an amazing job! I think that in the book Lan Zhan had a more emotion (and maybe talked a little more) than he did in the live-action series. I loved how the smallest details meant something really big and important (in the novel) and now it all makes sense to me in terms of probable “fan service” in the show.

Due to the fact that I read the book after watching the live-action series, I went into the book interpreting some of the BL content as almost fan fiction-like. The further in I got, however, the more I let my mind be open to the possibility of multiple interpretations of a work on screen. The Untamed and Mo Dao Zu Shi are really just that different. One can easily be confused as fan fiction for the other even though it’s not.

A note: whether watching or reading, these characters all have 2-4+ names/titles so you might want to keep track of it all somehow at the beginning b/c it can get very confusing very quickly and become overwhelming. Some suggestions I’ve read is to keep the Wiki page open until one has gotten the hang of all the names/titles; another is writing them down on a sticky note; and yet another could be having the character guide from the translations in one tap while watch or reading in another (if this is on a computer or phone.) Unfortunately, I didn’t use a character guide of any kind and just painfully figured it out as I went along...please save yourself that pain if you can.

———

One thing I will note is that the list of content warnings I will provide at the end are very important to bare in mind as you read since this isn't "YA" by any means. As a cognitively disabled and queer individual, I was taken a bit aback at times but there were far more times that I was laughing so hard my stomach hurt or crying or yelling at my phone screen because I couldn't throw my phone across the room like I would have with a book.

I have new ships btw! I always thought my favorite bromance ship would always be Sasuke and Naruto...but it looks like the canon ship of Wei Ying and Lan Zhan has sailed! But my hopeful new ships (Lan Sizhui x Jin Ling) still percists! I hope the author writes something about those two in the future as a spin-off somehow. I just really wish Chinese laws about not showing LGBTQ+ couples on TV didn't exist!!!!!

I took these content warnings from another reviewer but I do think they are important to add in b/c there are so many to be touched on. This is definitely an Adult Historical Chinese Fantasy work. I think the work is for mature audiences so read at your own risk. :)

❌ Content Warnings:
[Graphic: Sexual content (the sexually explicit scenes are in chapters chapter 95, chapter 111, and chapter 112 and those chapters can be easily skipped if you'd rather not read them), alcoholism, blood, body horror, child abuse, cursing, death, death of a parent, death of a sibling, death of a friend, emotional abuse, genocide, gore, grief, homophobia, kidnapping, medical content, medical trauma, murder, panic attacks/disorders, physical abuse, suicide, torture, and violence.

Moderate to minor: Sexual assault, self-harm, ableism, mentioned incest, rape, cannibalism, eating disorder, child death, work/death camp-like setting, very dubious consent, and corporal punishment.
